food.description: Taste, quality, portion, ingredients, cooking, specific dishes.

place.description: Physical space, layout, seating, crowding, bar area, size, cleanliness of space.

ambience.description: Atmospheric or emotional vibe: lighting, decor, energy, noise, mood.

service.description: Operational aspects: speed, wait times, reservation issues, understaffing.
examples: There was only one waiter for the whole room.

staff.description: Behavior or attitude of individual employees: friendliness, rudeness, attentiveness.

examples: The menu had great vegetarian options.
They ran out of my favorite dish.

miscellaneous.description: Content unrelated to the restaurant experience or no clear aspect match.
examples: We came here after visiting the museum.

polarity_rules.positive: Use when the reviewer expresses satisfaction, praise, liking, beauty, or appreciation.
polarity_rules.negative: Use for complaints, problems, irritation, frustration, or negative evaluations.
polarity_rules.neutral: Use for factual statements without emotional judgment.

positive.Appreciation: Grateful recognition of effort or thoughtfulness.
positive.Relief: Positive feeling when a worry is removed.

negative.Frustration: Repeated or significant obstacles; stronger irritation.
negative.Confusion: Lack of clarity or puzzling experience.
negative.Fear: Safety concerns or feelings of danger.

place_vs_ambience.place: Use when talking about physical layout, space, seating, bars, size, tables, or crowding.
place_vs_ambience.ambience: Use for mood, decor, lighting, temperature, noise, or atmospheric energy.

staff_vs_service.staff: Use when reviewing individual employee behavior (rude, friendly, cold, pushy).
staff_vs_service.service: Use when referring to the restaurant's operational process (wait times, understaffing, bad system).

when_to_use_neutral: Mentions of location choices (e.g., 'we sat at the bar').
Descriptions without opinion or emotional content.

multi_label_rules.definition: Tag multiple aspects when a sentence discusses more than one distinct entity.

examples.sentence: The waiter rushed us but the dining room was beautiful.
We sat at the bar and the bartender was lovely.
